back: A mathematical object that can be represented by an indexed collection of numbers, where the number of indices (i.e., the order) can be greater than 1.
A tensor of order two; a matrix can be visualized as a two-dimensional array of numbers.
A matrix for which the number of rows equals the number of columns.
For an $m \times m$ matrix, the main diagonal or principal diagonal is the vector of \(m\) elements at the indices \(k, k\) for \(k=0,1,\ldots, m-1\).
A square matrix  for which the only nonzero components are along the main diagonal.

A square \(m \times m\) matrix is an upper triangular matrix if its only nonzero elements are in the main diagonal and above; in other words, the only nonzero elements are those at positions \(k,l\) that satisfy \(l \ge k\).

A square \(m \times m\) matrix is a lower triangular matrix if its only nonzero elements are in the main diagonal and below; in other words, the only nonzero elements are those at positions \(k,l\) that satisfy \(l \le k\).
A square \(m \times m\) matrix (two-dimensional array) that is an upper triangular matrix or lower triangular matrix.

A diagonal matrix in which the off-diagonal entries are all zero and the diagonal entries are all equal to 1. The \(m \times  m\) identity matrix is denoted \(\mathbf{I}_m\). If $I_{j,k}$ denotes the entry in row $j$ and column $k$, then $I_{j,k}=1$ if $j=k$ and $I_{j,k}=0$ if  $j \ne k$.
